Award.AwardTitle: EAGER-NEON: Disentangling the Roles of Ecological and Historical Processes in Community Structure: A Continental-Scale Approach
Award.AbstractNarration:
The proposed research aims to improve our understanding of how communities of species, particularly plant species, are assembled and maintained over time. The species composition of ecosystems and habitats varies significantly by region and habitat type, and the effects of evolutionary processes can be obscured by contemporary ecological interactions unless confounding factors are carefully considered. The proposed research will address this problem by providing critical context for identifying the roles of ecological and historical processes in community assembly. This effort will bring a unique and unprecedented dataset to bear on central questions in community ecology while contributing to the understanding of sensitive biomes facing increased pressure from climate change and invasive species. The historical perspective introduced by the proposed framework will significantly improve the understanding of plant diversity and patterns of community structure at both local and continental scales, and serve as a model for future studies of community structure.

The proposed research will combine phylogenetic data with NEON data on species occurrence, abundance, and traits to test the relative roles of ecological and historical processes in governing plant community assembly. This includes evaluation of aspects of how established communities either accommodate or resist non-native species. Three specific questions will be addressed, focusing on woody perennials (e.g. trees, shrubs, cactuses, lianas): (1) How have historical processes shaped patterns of community structure? (2) How have species functional traits shaped patterns of community structure? (3) Are communities of closely related species more susceptible to non-native species invasion? Analyses will be conducted using a broad array of ecological and evolutionary comparative and analytical computational methods. For phylogenetic analyses, the PIs will obtain sequence data for all woody perennials recorded within each NEON-sampled plot by first mining the GenBank database for publically available sequences, and will fill in any missing data by generating new sequences using tissue samples obtained from herbarium samples.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Why do particular species live together, while others don't? Identifying the factors that influence community structure has long been a challenge, especially because patterns of biodiversity can vary with spatial and taxonomic scale, and historical processes can be obscured by more recent ecological interactions among species. This project sought to overcome these challenges by conducting a large-scale study of woody perennial plant communities across the United States. This involved utilizing plant community data collected by the National Ecological Observatory Network (NEON).

First, we showed that speciation, extinction and dispersal explained why species co-occur within 57% of the communities we examined. For the remaining 43% of communities, species composition was likely shaped by more recent ecological processes.

Second, we gained insights on why some communities are more susceptible to the establishment of non-native species. We showed that the number of non-native species increased when communities of native species were less phylogenetically diverse. This suggests that less diverse communities may be less resistant to species invasions. We also showed that in some communities, non-native species co-occurred with native species to which they were closely related.

Third, we showed that genome duplication (polyploidy) played an important role in whether species from two plant families, Brassicaceae and Rosaceae, co-occurred. In particular, we found that polyploid species tend to be more distantly related to diploids found within the same community than those diploids are to each other. This suggests that polyploid species are unlikely to establish within the same community as their diploid ancestors.

Overall, our work showed that phylogenetic relationships can reveal important details about why particular species live together. However, the community patterns we found were not consistent across all communities. Therefore, despite the increase in studies using phylogenetic relationships to predict species co-occurrence, our work highlights that additional types of data (e.g. data on plant traits) should also be incorporated into studies.

During our project, we also identified a need to create a program that could take advantage of the large number of publicly-available digitized plant specimens and the wealth of information harbored in them. Leaf area and shape can provide important insights into the ecology and evolutionary history of plant species, and biologists have typically hand measured these traits. This time-consuming and labor-intensive task has meant that data sets are often limited in size and scope. We therefore developed LeafMachine, an open-source application that autonomously measures leaves from digitized herbarium specimen using an ensemble of machine learning algorithms (www.leafmachine.org).

This grant provided research and professional development opportunities for nine diverse students (two high school and seven undergraduate students). This grant also provided us opportunities to engage with K-12 children to foster an interest in science. We developed and ran workshops for the American Association of University Women’s Expanding Your Horizons conference, which targets middle school girls, and developed activities for Evolution Family Day at the University of Colorado Boulder’s Museum of Natural History. We were also involved in Letters to a Pre-Scientist, which pairs scientists with a student from an under-resourced community, and Planting Science, which connects botanists with middle school students to help design and conduct research on plants.
